nodes.title: Phylogenies: How we sketch the Tree of Life (Tyrone Ly)
nodes.description: Phylogenies: How we sketch the Tree of Life

typeData.textContent:
In this week’s lecture, we were introduced to a tree-like (or bush-like) diagram which is comprised by a wide variety of organisms, ranging from the simplest to the most complex form. In fact, this model does not only demonstrate the knowledge of biodiversity but also summarizes the evolution of all species that inhabit the Earth in a well-organized chronological order. It is a phylogeny, or in other words, a phylogenetic tree.

          By definition, phylogenies are visual representations for the hypotheses of how different species are related to each other through inheritance and evolution from a common ancestor (Baum, 2008). They were developed as an appreciation for Darwin’s Theory of Evolution, and indeed evolutionary biologists have been using them since the time of Darwin. However, before our scientists finally arrived at the consensus of “tree thinking”, many models have been proposed as explanations for the evolution of species, including a well-known one, which you may have been able to guess, the “ladder of life” (Baum, 2008).

          Ladder models were introduced with a belief that humans are the most advanced species of all kinds, and the degree of perfection gradually increases along the ladder from the most primitive to its peak where mankind stands. According to Dr. Baum (2008), though this misleading viewpoint was firmly rejected by many biologists and even by Darwin, it is still existing amongst our daily life owing largely to the media, whose knowledge of evolutionary biology is undeniably limited. 

           The aforementioned reason is why phylogenies are common mostly to the intellectuals, such as scientists or university students, but not the general public. Despite this, reading and interpreting phylogenies are critical skills that require practice, and surprisingly a rigorous understanding of these diagrams have only been developed over the past few decades (Baum, 2008). We, as students, would have easily misinterpreted the concepts of evolution through the use of phylogenies without prior knowledge of how they work. 

           These trees can have several appearances, which ranges from V-shaped, U-shaped, circular, to the bush-like diagram as in lecture, etc. To understand phylogenies, we can think of them as zoomed-out versions of numerous pedigrees (Baum, 2008), which are charts used for tracking the inheritance of phenotypes within families or populations. As long as there is gene flow between certain populations, they will be grouped together to form a branch (or lineage) on the grand tree. Thus, where a branch splits is where evolution has occurred and the difference in genotype between the new populations continues to increase over the course of time, leading to the emergence of new species. 

          Over billions of years of evolution, many species have come to existence as of nowadays, and nevertheless many have also come to extinction. Each of them is represented by either a formerly produced or a new budding twig on the tree, and as Darwin have said, “[T]he Tree of Life … covers the earth with ever-branching and beautiful ramifications” (Baum, 2008).


References
Baum, D. (2008) Reading a Phylogenetic Tree: The Meaning of Monophyletic Groups. Nature Education 1(1):190, https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/reading-a-phylogenetic-tree-the-meaning-of-41956/ 
Baum, D. (2008) Trait evolution on a phylogenetic tree: Relatedness, similarity, and the myth of evolutionary advancement. Nature Education 1(1):191, https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/trait-evolution-on-a-phylogenetic-tree-relatedness-41936/

nodes.title: Evolution and Survival (Simon Kim)
nodes.description:
Works Cited
https://www.yourgenome.org/facts/what-is-evolution

typeData.textContent:
First we must differentiate between evolution and adaptations. 

Evolution is the change in the frequency of a gene or trait in a population over multiple generations. 
Adaptation are a trait that increases reproductive success. (Produced by natural selection) (Adaptions are environmentally determined).

Charles Darwin's theory of evolution states that evolution occurs through the process of natural selection.  So what is natural selection?

Natural selection is the process in which an organism who has better characteristics which are better suited towards their environment are more likely to survive. By avoiding predators and being able to find mates their ability to pass their genes onto the next generation is higher than those who are not adept to their environment. 

Next to evolution stands adaptive radiation. Adaptive radiation is when an species splits off into a variety of new forms due to the changes to their environment. An excellent example of this would be the Galapagos Islands and the finches that reside on it. Each island with its different environment have made the finches to undergo adaptive radiation to better suit each island. The shapes of the beaks change with the type of food that is on each island to better suit the bird's survival on each island.

In 1859, an English naturalist Charles Darwin publish his theory of evolution by natural selection in his best-selling book, On the Origin of Species. His theory suggests that individuals with traits better suited to the environment than others have a better change to survive and reproduce. They are able to pass their adaptive traits onto their offspring. Over generations, creatures with these adaptive traits would take up a higher proportion in their population. If the environment changes rapidly, some species may not be able to adapt fast enough through natural selection, this may lead to the extinction of these species.
Today, human actions such as overhunting and the destruction of habitats are the main cause of extinctions. Extinctions seem to be occurring at a much faster rate today than they did in the past, as shown in the fossil record.(National Geographic Society, 2019)
Is natural selection still happening on humans nowadays?
In a world of globalization, rapidly advancing medical and genetic science and the increasing power of individuals to determine their own life choices, Some of us may wonder whether we are still affected by natural selection. "Natural selection, if it hasn't stopped, has at least slowed down," says Professor Steve Jones, UCL geneticist. (Jones, 2011) However some traits are still appears to be operated by natural selection. Based on a research done by Stephen Stearns, human heights are reduced and weight are slightly increased. However, these changes were very small and slow. “Rather than sheltering us from natural selection, the changes that we've made to the world may actually be driving our evolution.” (Stearns, 2011) Since the high-speed development of human civilization, Natural selection for human beings may be getting a redefinition.
Reference:
https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-12535647
https://www.nationalgeographic.org/encyclopedia/natural-selection/

Misconceptions about evolution 

"We are on top of the evolutionary ladder and we are the most superior species that there was and there ever will be"  

This is a very common misconception that humans are the pinnacle of evolution and we are the top of the evolutionary ladder. However, this proves to be a very egocentrism view because evolution does not stop at Homo Sapiens - it is constantly happening, even though it is a very slow process. Humans have actually been around very recently relative to some species who have been around for hundreds of millions of years, and to say that Sapiens is the furthest evolution can go is simply not true.

“Evolution can only happen slowly and gradually.” 

It is true that throughout the history of life, evolution has been shown to occur in a very slow fashion, spanning over millions of years. However, evolution does not necessarily have to be slow, as scientists have discovered that some species have undergone extremely rapid changes to cope with the changing of their environment. For instance, we see natural selection occurring at a rapid rate to organisms who have to survive and adapt to an environment full of toxins released by human activity. We can observe this in marine animals, where oil is constantly dumped to the sea.  

“Evolution always results in perfect adaptability to the environment”  

It is important to note that evolution is not a process of an animal adapting to an environment like how a giraffe stretches its neck to reach the leaves at high altitude. Evolution’s first step, which is mutation in the genes, is a random event that can either result in traits that significantly decrease an organism’s chances of survival, or in traits that are beneficial to their survival. Since mutations are completely random, the design is never perfect, and there will always be new organisms that are more well-adapted to the environment than their predecessors. The takeaway is that evolution may result in an increase of the odds of survival for the organism, but the organism will never be perfectly adapted to the environment as they will always be vulnerable to something.  

“All traits must be adaptations to help an organism survive” 

While it is true that some traits help an organism to survive in its environment, others might just be a by-product of the development of other traits and they can be useful initially while being completely unnecessary later. For instance, a belly button was initially important because this was the passage for the umbilical cord for the mother to give nutrients to the offspring. However, it is completely useless as the human offspring becomes detached to the mother.

“Similar traits must surely mean they are from the same origins” 
 
While biologists use similarities between species to determine their common ancestors - which are known as homologous traits- some traits actually developed independently from each other but just happen to share similarities. This is known as analogous traits, where similar traits develop independently on different branches of the phylogenetic tree. 

“All the traits observed were meant to perform its current functions only” 

Some traits were meant to perform a certain function, however, they were later used by the organism to perform other functions as well. For instance, feathers were initially meant for insulation to shield birds from the cold. However, it was later co-opted for them to use for flying as well. These are known as exaptations.

"Monkeys were our ancestors" 

This is a very common belief because we share more than 90% of our genetic makeup with chimpanzees. In reality, both humans and chimpanzees share the same common ancestor - an ape-like creature. This means Sapiens are more like cousins to the great apes as opposed to being their descendants.

Epigenetic Therapy for Cancer Treatment (Cindy Hsu) [brainfreeze]

typeData.textContent:
Cancer was originally thought of as a genetic disease, with the root of the disease being its direct damage to cell DNA. More recently, cancer has been discovered to have both genetic and epigenetic components (“Epigenetic Therapy”, 2007), although the mixture depends on the specific cancer type. 

Epigenetics is the study of the expression of information in genes (i.e. a person's phenotype), which can change without the underlying gene sequence changing. A person's epigenetics can change throughout their lifetime through biological processes such as DNA methylation and histone modification, which are caused by environmental exposure, choice of diet, and other lifestyle factors. These epigenetic changes also accumulate over a person's life as a possible byproduct of cell division.

This mention of cell division is especially critical in relation to cancer. Although harmful epigenetic changes are a component in other diseases such as diabetes and asthma (Kelly, Theresa K, et al., 2010), cancer causes accelerated and uncontrolled cell growth which allows these epigenetic changes to accumulate faster than they would have through natural aging. According to a study by Kelly et al. in 2010, cancer also causes a global loss in DNA methylation levels. One avenue of epigenetic therapy that is being explored is the possibility of reverting epigenetic changes in cancer-affected cells, in order to restore their normal function without having to resort to more extreme solutions (“Epigenetic Therapy”, 2007).

Chemotherapy, one of the most common forms of cancer treatment, relies on using strong doses of drugs to kill cancerous cells. These drugs often cause unwanted side effects in the patient (e.g. hair loss), as other rapidly dividing cells also become targets despite being non-cancerous. Over time, patients can also develop resistance to these drugs. Thus, other forms of epigenetic treatment focus on using epigenetics in combination with other methods, such as by improving the effectiveness of chemotherapy by increasing responsiveness (Kelly, Theresa K, et al., 2010). 

Epigenetic therapy has successfully been used to treat cancers that affect the blood, bone marrow, or lymph nodes, through two specific FDA-approved treatments (Kelly, Theresa K, et al., 2010). There has been little success in using this method against solid cancers (tumors), but as the treatment method is still relatively new, there is still much to be studied.

Sources

“Epigenetic Therapy.” PBS, PBS, 16 Oct. 2007, www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/article/epigenetic-therapy/.

Hellebrekers, Debby, and Manon van Engeland. “Epigenetic Therapy.” SpringerLink, Springer Nature, 10 Mar. 2017, link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-642-16483-5_1948.

Kelly, Theresa K, et al. “Epigenetic Modifications as Therapeutic Targets.” Nature Biotechnology, vol. 28, no. 10, Oct. 2010, pp. 1069–1078., doi:10.1038/nbt.1678.

nodes.title: Gene Expression and Epigenetic Mechanisms Quiz (Liane Tang)
Dominant and Recessive Alleles Fill in the Blank (Michelle Tang)

typeData.textContent:
DNA methylation is one of the two epigenetic mechanisms that can modify gene expression. During DNA methylation, a methyl group is added to the cytosine base of one’s DNA, which will modify the function of the genes and therefore which genes will be expressed. 

This process can be interrupted due to a variety of environmental factors as well as just factors that play a role purely due to chance (Jin & Robertson, 2011). If DNA methylation were to be interrupted or is inhibited from happening as it should, consequences including various diseases are likely to occur. Scientists have concluded that cancer, lupus, muscular dystrophy, and different birth defects are linked to methylation abnormalities (Phillps, 2008). 

In an individual with cancer, for example, an increase in methylation in one’s body may lead to tumor suppressor genes being silenced, and therefore the cancer is able to cause more detrimental consequences to one’s health and ability to recover. 

Epigenetic modifications to the human kind, such as those done through DNA methylation, are essential to the development of the species (Jin & Robertson, 2011). 

References:
Jin, B., Li, Y., & Robertson, K. D. (2011). DNA methylation: Superior or subordinate in the epigenetic hierarchy? Genes & Cancer, 2(6), 607-617. doi:10.1177/1947601910393957

Phillips, T. (2008). The role of methylation in gene expression. Nature Education 1(1), 116

nodes.title: Interactions between Gene-Environment: Twins (Navin Johal)
nodes.description: Overview of Epigenetics influencing gene-environment interactions and how twins are used to understand the influences of nature vs nurture

typeData.textContent:
Epigenetics is the study of gene-environment interactions and how the same genotype can lead to multiple different phenotypes. Since genes don’t happen within a vacuum the environment plays a role in determining the combination of when and how genes express themselves. In order to determine the relative contribution of genetic and environment has on an individual monozygotic and dizygotic twin are studied to compare the effects genes play if twins are raised in the same environment. Monozygotic twins are born with the same genotype since they come from the same zygote and dizygotic twins are born from two different zygotes. This is how the study on epigenetics occurs by studying the relationship and influence between environment and genetic inheritance by comparing identical and fraternal twins.
	Gene-environment interactions can’t be discussed without first mentioning range of reaction which asserts that our genes set the boundaries within which we can operate, and our environment interacts with the genes to determine where in that range we will fall. To put it into simpler terms, genes are the limit of an individual’s potential and it is up to the environment to determine how much of that potential is fulfilled. Therefore, it is not an additive variable but a combined variable that depend on each other. Resulting in a correlation between gene-environment termed as genetic environmental correlation stating that our genes influence our environment and our environment influences our genes. Range of reaction describes the relationship of how genes and environment interact with each other furthermore, genetic environmental correlation explains how the two variables influence each other. 
	The result of genetic and environmental conditions combining results in behaviour which can be studies directly by researchers. Since both have an important role, genes contain the response of evolution of predecessors on selecting certain behaviours (refer to Proof of Evolution by Dylan Painter) and environment gives the opportunity for animals to adjust their behaviour according to experiences in their lifetime. One example of behaviour being influenced by genetic and environmental conditions is courtship display (refer to Mating in the Animal World: Examples of Courtship Display by Harry Chae) which describes how different species have distinct ways of trying to court a mate into sexual selection based on display. 
	By studying twins’ researchers can better understand the effects nature vs nurture has on specific traits under study by using identical and fraternal twins as a guideline to determine the degree of influence either component of environment or genomes may have on an individual. Studying identical twins allows researchers to be able to isolate the variable of environmental conditions since the control variable the genome is the same between twins. Therefore, the degree of influence the environment has for a trait under study can be extrapolated from the data and observations collected. For fraternal twins the contrary can be studied by controlling the variable of environment by making it similar between twins. This time however, the genome will vary since the twins were born from separate zygotes therefore, the effect genes have on a particular trait under study can be extracted from the data collected to evaluate the influence of genotype on an individual.
	This is useful way to analyze influence of nature vs nurture under the study of certain diseases to determine the mechanism and origin of particular illnesses. Such as schizophrenia, which is higher chance to develop in identical twins compared to fraternal twins. Indicating genomes play a role in developing the disease however other factors that the environment can present can play a significant role as well. The model of monozygotic and dizygotic twins to extrapolate data from specific traits of interest has been proven to provide insight and understanding for researchers studying epigenetics.

 

Insights from Identical Twins. (n.d.). Retrieved July 15, 2020, from https://learn.genetics.utah.edu/content/epigenetics/twins/

Both Environment and Genetic Makeup Influence Behavior. (n.d.). Retrieved July 15, 2020, from https://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/both-environment-and-genetic-makeup-influence-behavior-13907840/

nodes.title: Epigenetics: Drag the Word Activity (Stefanie Fylypchuk)

typeData.textContent: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a condition that affects an individual’s social skill, communication skills, and behavior towards certain situations. Autism is primarily a genetic condition as most of the risk for this disorder stems from genes. There are gene mutations that can lead to this condition and can be detected by four types of tests. However, there are no genetic testing that can specifically diagnose or detect autism, only ones that can detect genetic mutations that might possibly lead to the disorder. This is because there is no such thing as an autism gene. Autism is considered a genetic illness is because its the changes, or mutations in the DNA of certain genes that lead to this illness. Although there are genetic tests that can help identify whether a child has a genetic mutation that can possibly help connect their deficits in their development to Autism, the most accurate way to detect this disorder is through assessments throughout a child’s development, referencing developmental norms.

What is a dominant allele? 
A dominant allele is a gene sequence that will show in the final product (phenotype). In Heim 1991 article on recessive alleles, he touches on the possibility to be able to calculate the “degree of dominance” of an allele. The equation used is (Heterozygous value) - (recessive value) / (Dominant value) - (recessive value). Moreover, there are three types of dominant alleles; complete, incomplete, and codominance. A complete dominant allele is what is most common and seen in most allele-based coding. Hair colour is an example of using a complete dominant allele. An incomplete allele is when two dominant alleles join to make a different phenotype, of which it is not like any of the two alleles. For example, if a blue flower allele mixes with a white flower allele, it would produce a light blue flower. Lastly, a codominant allele is when both alleles in the pair show in the final product. For example, if a brown cow allele paired with a white cow allele, the final product would be a brown and white spotted cow. 

What is a recessive allele? 
A recessive allele is a gene sequence that will never show unless the dominant pair is heterozygous. Heterozygous alleles mean that the allele sequence is one dominant and one recessive (Hh). In doing so, there is a 25% chance of the final product have the recessive gene. 

How this relates to epigenetics? 
Alleles play a large role in decoding genes to get the phenotype. The addition of epigenetics, with the histone remodeling and DNA methylation changes the results of the phenotype. In turn, this completely disregards how alleles help with defining the phenotype for the final product. 
 
References 
Heim, W. (1991). What Is a Recessive Allele? The American Biology Teacher, 53(2), 94-97. doi:10.2307/4449229 
Biologydictionary.net Editors. (2016, December 06). Dominant Allele. Retrieved from https://biologydictionary.net/dominant-allele/

Genes and environment regarding learning (Scott Weber)
nodes.description: I relate learning in different environments using the Cooper and Zubek study.

typeData.textContent:
Cooper and Zubek showed that the entire discussion should not be purely about the genes you already have. Tyron explored the idea of selective breeding to create the best maze running rat. Tryon’s experiment clearly shows that genes can influence the potential maze running ability of the rats. There is another side of the story however, the environment. Cooper and Zubek took the selectively bred rats and placed them into two environments, Impoverished and enriched. Environment definitely matters - they found important information about how the environment acts with natural potential. The maze dull rats from enriched environments outperformed (fewer maze errors) than maze dull from impoverished environments and, in fact they almost performed better than maze bright rats from impoverished environments. Additionally there is a much larger gap between maze bright and dull in the impoverished environment than enriched. As expected, maze bright rats in an enriched environment performed the best overall.

I believe that this experiment is very important applied to real life because it shows how the environment plays a moderately sized role in performance. This experiment shows that in the right environment someone can more easily maximize their potential. Applying this to real life in the sense of economic disparities the same premise makes sense. People with high socioeconomic status and funds, can afford to support and create a positive environment for their children. In a study looking at learning in kids with lower socioeconomic status found that “The findings of this study also reinforce the importance of teachers’ expectations of their students’ academic promise” (Barbarin 104). Just the expectations that the children were less able to learn was harmful. Different teaching loads and teacher inexperience were also linked to achievement. Teachers of low income areas were also more likely to be inexperienced (105). All these things come together to show that the environment that children are placed into does change how effective the learning they do is. Not only do lower socioeconomic children have a worse environment for learning, they are also less likely to be challenged with advanced material instead focusing on more basic skills (103). This means that they will have to work even harder to get out of the current situation or they will be stuck. I believe that if we want to create change in poverty and educational disparities we need to invest more in schools and use studies like these. One way to break the loop is providing proper education to as many people as we can.

I had no idea before doing further research how different education can be for higher socioeconomic people. The idea that a teacher's perception of how a student will do also got me thinking about some of my highschool classes where I believed that the teacher thought I would not be able to do something. When we talk about socioeconomic status and creating change there are some many moving pieces but I think that it is important to look at one problem from many different perspectives to identify how to create a plan and move forward.

Bibliography:

Barbarin, Oscar A., and Nikki Aikens. “Overcoming the Educational Disadvantages of Poor Children: How Much Do Teacher Preparation, Workload, and Expectations Matter.” American Journal of Orthopsychiatry, vol. 85, no. 2, 2015, pp. 101–105., doi:10.1037/ort0000060.

nodes.title: Natural Selection of Sickle-Cell Anaemia (Megan Ho)

typeData.textContent:
Sickle-cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disease, which means it can only be inherited when both parents carry the defective gene. When an individual has sickle-cell anaemia, their red blood cells are mutated from a regular round shape to an abnormal crescent-moon shape. Sickled red blood cells can clog blood vessels and result in various physiological problems, such as intense fevers, chess pains, and damage to bone due to lack of oxygen supply. Individuals with sickle-cell anaemia usually die at an early age. 

According to natural selection, traits that increase an individual’s chances of survival are more likely to be passed onto future generations. Given that individuals diagnosed with sickle-cell anaemia typically do not live long enough to reproduce, the likelihood of inheriting the defective gene gradually decreases over time. In most parts of the world, such as in North American and European countries, this form of natural selection can be observed, whereby individuals with the sickle-cell defective gene are selected against. However, in places like Africa and Southeast Asia, individuals with the sickle-cell gene are actually selected for. As mentioned earlier, sickle-cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means that individuals carrying one copy of the sickle cell gene do not suffer from the disease. In fact, these individuals have a selective advantage, because carrying the sickle-cell gene results in immunity to malaria, a lethal disease common in tropical climates. Being immune to malaria, these carrier individuals have increased fitness, and by natural selection, this results in a higher chance of survival and passing their genes to their offspring. Thus, in tropical areas where malaria is prevalent, the sickle cell gene is still commonly detected in populations. 

References 
Luzzatto, Lucio. “Sickle Cell Anaemia And Malaria.” Mediterranean Journal of Hematology and Infectious Diseases, vol. 4, no. 1, 2012, doi:10.4084/mjhid.2012.065.

While Charles Darwin was not the first to think of evolution, he did create large amounts of evidence supporting the idea. In modern times, there are a number of diverse fields of evidence supporting the theory of evolution from bones to embryo development, some going beyond the evidence Darwin first came up with. 

Part of the evidence from the bones of living beings is the similarities in some types of animals. Mammals, for example, have similar bones, though it may not seem like it at first. The wings of a bat are in the same area as your fingers and have the same basic bone structure. The pattern of bones are the same in both bats and humans, although bat "fingers" are much larger compared to the rest of the body. Whale fin bones are also the same order. Mammals  have the same general structure of bones, just modified for different purposes, such as swimming, running, or flying. 

	Another piece of evidence is the existence of vestigial structures. Vestigial structures are parts of the body that serve little to no purpose, but might have served a function in ancestral species of the animals. One example is a leg bone in a whale, which remains inside the body of the whale its whole life. While it is not useful for the whale, it was useful for when its ancestors walked on land. 

	A surprising piece of evidence for evolution is found in the development of embryos. In frogs, the embryos pass through a larval stage in the, with features of normally aquatic larvae. However, they hatch ready to live on land, suggesting an ancestral species that had a larval stage. 

	Supporting evidence for evolution also came up in geography. In the past, the continents were arranged in a different pattern than they are today, such as South America and Africa being connected. This leads to a single species of animal or plant being able to exist on multiple continents, and then become different species after the continents split, should evolution be true. As that is what we see, evolution gets more supporting evidence. 

	You can learn more about misconceptions of evolution in "Common misconceptions of evolution by Hary Chae." Another interesting part of evolution is courtship displays, which help the creation of new species by creating a barrier between groups.  More information on those can be found in “Mating in the animal world: Examples of Courtship displays by Harry.” A quiz about epigenetics can be found in “transgenerational epigenetics quiz (Navin Johal)”


Bibliography

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidence_of_common_descent

nodes.title: The 4 requirements for Natural Selection (Amir Hosseini)

typeData.textContent:
As presented in week 7, lecture 2,  natural selection is one of the main contributors of evolution on this planet. Natural selection acts as a filter that only allows certain traits to pass through, hence pass on and reproduce. Natural selection occurs when individuals with advantageous traits reproduce and pass on their genes, and species without those traits face difficulty surviving. Those traits are what affects the biological fitness of species, species with the advantageous trait are more likely to survive and mate, yet species without those traits fail to survive and reproduce; thus, having a lower biological fitness. However, there are four requirements that Darwin found critical for natural selection to take place.

Firstly, the organisms in the population must vary in traits to allow natural selection to take place. For instance, looking at a population of birds, there must be variations in size or colour for natural selection to occur. Variability in traits leads to variability in fitness, which leads to selection.

Secondly, such traits must be heritable, meaning they can be passed on. For natural selection to occur, genes of specific characteristics must be passed on to future generations, thus evolving the particular specie.

Thirdly, there must be a variation in survival rates (competition). Meaning that species must compete to survive, thus certain traits will become advantageous to those who carry the genes for it; hence they will have higher biological fitness, thus survive and reproduce.

Lastly, the individuals with the advantageous trait must adapt to the environment and survive and reproduce. Those individuals cannot be a random sample of the population, meaning that they must make up the population. 

Source:
Freeman, S., Harrington, M., & Sharp, J. (2014). Biological science. Toronto: Pearson.

nodes.title: Nature vs. Nurture (June Hayashi)
nodes.description: Relevant studies about the interplay of genetics and environment in the behavior of a study

typeData.textContent:
Behavioral psychology aims to understand to what extent genes and environment are responsible for the behaviors of a species. There are some traits that have more obvious evolutionary roles such as the ability to acquire food or avoiding predators. However, there are some traits that are less obvious such as learning ability or social dominance and status that play an important role in the survival of a species. Through different studies that use selective breeding, scientists have been able to uncover the role that genetics and environment play in the evolutionary success of a species. 
     In one study the interplay of social dominance and genetics has been tested through artificial selection on cockroaches. The were able to conclude that the cockroaches of higher social status and dominance were more successful in reproducing. The pheromonal presentation of the more dominance was a trait that was passed down to their offspring (Moore et al., 2002). 
The beginning of behavioral genetics began in testing the learning ability of rats. Maze “bright” and “dull” were selectively bread and Tryon and Tolman each played a significant role in understanding the genetics of learning (Innis, 1992). 
     Cooper and Zubek conducted a study to see the how rats fared in “enriched” versus “impoverished” environments. Their study demonstrated that genetic factors were not solely responsible for the learning ability of the rats. In enriched environments maze dull rats performed better and in impoverished environments maze bright rats performed more poorly (Cooper and Zubek 1958). 
     The next step would be to understand the impact that similar situations would have on people. Is the learning of a child of a child inhibited when their school is in a louder environment, such as near an airport? Do genetics also play a significant role in the social dominance in people? The field of evolutionary genetics in psychology still has many unanswered questions.

Cooper, R. M., & Zubek, J. P. (1958). Effects of enriched and restricted early environments on the 
    learning ability of bright and dull rats. Canadian Journal of Psychology/Revue canadienne de 
    psychologie, 12(3), 159–164. https://doi.org/10.1037/h0083747

Innis, N. K. (1992). Tolman and Tryon: Early research on the inheritance of the ability to learn. 
    American Psychologist, 47(2), 190–197. https://doi.org/10.1037/0003-066X.47.2.190

Moore, A., Haynes, K., Preziosi, R., & Moore, P. (2002). The Evolution of Interacting Phenotypes: 
    Genetics and Evolution of Social Dominance. The American Naturalist, 160(S6). doi:10.1086/342899

nodes.title: Natural Selection vs. Transgenerational Epigenetics (Khatija Quadre)

typeData.textContent:
Evolution is a necessary means for the survival of a species and occurs over generations. It is the idea that populations of species change over time through generations. Traditionally, it is considered that it occurs according to Darwin’s theory of Evolution. This theory suggests that species undergo descent with modification, all species come from pre-existing species, and all species can trace their descent to a common ancestor.  Darwin introduced the evolutionary mechanism of natural selection which proposes that inherited traits that are more effective for surviving and reproduction of an individual in a given environment will tend to become more common in the following generations.  In cases of behaviour, certain behaviours can promote the survival of species. For example, social dominance is a trait for which, within some species, dominant males copulate more than non-dominant males. Another is courtship display, where within many species, individuals with more intricate series of courtship displays copulate more. This is thought to promote the evolution of new species through a behavioural barrier causing speciation. 
	A species is a group of organisms that is reproductively isolated from other organisms. This is caused by speciation (formation of a new species due to evolution) which occurs through different kinds of barriers such as geographical, temporal, behavioural, gametic, and mechanical. Each of these barriers works in a different method, however, they all lead to species being unable to interbreed, and being unable to produce viable, fertile offspring. Therefore, traditionally this is thought to be the method of evolution, where the genes (may arise from mutations) that are the ones that are suitable for a species in a certain environment are more commonly passed down. 
	Another process that affects the expressed phenotype is epigenetics. Epigenetics causes changes in phenotype by any means other than changes in the underlying DNA, unlike mutations that alter the nucleotide sequence in DNA. These changes most commonly seem to occur from either DNA methylation or histone remodelling. Epigenetics is fairly similar to the idea of Lamarckism (rather than Darwin’s theory) which implies that behavioural and physical traits passed onto subsequent generations is a function of the experience of the individual during a lifetime.
	These epigenetic changes which occur most commonly from the two well-known marks above during an individual’s lifetime are reprogrammed across most of the genome during the early stages of embryonic development from parent to offspring. This should establish a clean slate for the next generation. Therefore, according to the traditional view, we can expect that what we do to our body during our life should have little effect if any on our children or grandchildren. We would expect our offspring to be safe from any environmental events or toxins we encounter within our lives. However, according to recent research epigenetic changes that occur within our lives such as DNA methylation can be transmitted to subsequent generations. Therefore, what we expose our own bodies to, can have an effect on offspring and grand offspring. 
	 Whether it may occur through epigenetics or natural selection. Both processes seem to cause changes in species through an effect on gene expression. 

REFERENCES:
Barnes, S. (2020). Week 7, Lecture 3: Basics of Genetics and Epigenetics [Lecture Video PowerPoint]. Retrieved from Canvas.
Barnes, S. (2020). Week 7, Lecture 4: Evolution, Genetics, and Behaviour [Lecture Video PowerPoint]. Retrieved from Canvas.
“Species & speciation.” Khan Academy. Accessed July 15, 2020 www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/her/tree-of-life/a/species-speciation
“Darwin, evolution, & natural selection .” Khan Academy. Accessed July 15, 2020
www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/her/evolution-and-natural-selection/a/darwin-evolution-natural-selection
Barnes, Steven. AP Psych UBCx, 2016, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I2355VPUZf4

Homo sapiens. As humans, we are the only species of humans that exist today. As a species, we are reproductively isolated from all the rest of the different species of animals.

How can reproductive isolation occur?

Geographical isolation
occurs when two species live in different habitats or are physically separated from each other because they are stuck on different islands. 
for example, it would be possible for lions and tigers to mate to produce ligers/tigons if they are kept in captivity together.


Behavioural isolation
occurs when two species exhibit different courtship behaviour, which precedes mating, so that one does not consider the other “attractive” as a potential mate
for example, specific mating calls of certain species of birds will only attract members of the same species. 


Temporal isolation
occurs when two species do not develop sexual maturity at the same rate and will mate at different periods of the year.  
for example, different species of toads living in the same pond will not intermate because one species mates during spring while the other mates in the summer. 


Mechanical isolation
occurs when the genital organs of two species do not fit together due to different size or shape. 
for example, dogs that differ greatly in size would have difficulty mating. 


The above are pre-zygotic ways that organisms of different species cannot mate with each other, that is, no offspring will be produced at all. Post-zygotic isolation can also occur in which offspring can be produced but are either inviable or infertile (either the offspring themselves or the next generation).


Reference
“Species & speciation.” Khan Academy. Accessed July 11, 2020. https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/her/tree-of-life/a/species-speciation

The relationship between genes and the individual’s environment has become more recognized, ever since scientists began putting more emphasis on the nurture side of the nature-nurture debate. For example, identical twins have shown to grow up embodying different personalities, strengths, and weaknesses in addition to having different health conditions later in life - although they share an identical genetic makeup. The nature side of the debate argues the similarity between these individuals is attributed to genes.  However, the nurture side explains the phenomena of identical twins becoming very different people and having vastly different life experiences. For example, monozygotic twins separated at birth will not have identical external influences whether it be the people they spend time with, their lifestyle choices such as the food they consume, or the hobbies they pursue. These differences have shown to account for developmental differences, which proves that genetic makeup is not the sole guiding factor in how a person matures - physically and mentally. Thus, scientists have concluded that development is determined by a combination of the genetic makeup and the environment in which this development took place. Food is cooked through a combination of the ingredients used in the dish, and the way the chef chooses to prepare them - a meal can be changed drastically if the method of preparation changes, even if the same ingredients are being used in both. 

Heritability is the proportion of variation observed on a trait among individuals that can be attributed to their genes. We cannot determine how much of one person’s intelligence can be attributed to their genetic makeup versus their environment - however, we can estimate this when looking at population. To demonstrate this, take an example where 5 individuals are raised in 5 identical houses on the same street. Their living environments are 100% controlled and exactly the same - for example, they are all fed the same amount of food at the same time every day, and they all live in these conditions for the same period. Despite identical external factors, the variance between their intelligence will remain - mostly determined by their genes. When there is no difference between environments, it could not have impacted their intelligence in different ways. Thus, the logical conclusion is that their differences are caused by their differences in genotype. Therefore, this population has a high heritability estimate value.
 

 On the other hand, if we take 5 monozygotic twins with the same genetic makeup and raise them in drastically different environments - for example, them being on 5 different continents, living lifestyles with little overlap (living on a farm, living in a metropolitan city, living with a nomadic community, being raised in a forest, etc) and then compare IQ scores, the heritability estimate will be a lower value. This is because, in this situation, their environments account for a bigger percentage of their differences in intelligence. Living in such diverse environments was sure to influence the lifestyles and learnings of each child in many ways, thus their intelligence is determined less by the genetic code and attributed more to their exposure to these environments. 

To summarize, heritability looks at the relative contribution of genes to the variation in behaviour or traits within a population. As the environment becomes increasingly controlled, the heritability estimate's value increases because the variability can be attributed more to the nature side - their DNA. When DNA is the same and living conditions are distinct, the population’s heritability value goes down because the genes are contributing less to the trait's variance between each person.

nodes.title: New Approach to Nature-Nurture Dichotomy (Megan Ho)

typeData.textContent:
The nature-nurture dichotomy is an ongoing debate that reflects on the importance of genes and environmental factors on the development of behaviour. Nature refers to genetic contributions that are inherited from ancestors, while nurture refers to environmental factors, such as wealth and education level, which can continuously change over an individual's lifetime. 

For the longest time, psychologists and behaviourists have attempted to attribute behaviour to either one of genetics or the environment. For example, consider the intelligence of identical twins. Identical twins are 100% genetically similar, and given that they come from the same family, they would have relatively similar living and learning conditions. However, even with seemingly constant nature and nurture factors, it is not impossible for these twins to have drastically different levels of intelligence. In these cases, instead of trying to pin-point whether intelligence is affected by genes or the environment, it would be more useful to take into account the contributions of both nature and nurture to an individual's behaviour, and then rate the level of contributions between the two. 

The new approach to the nature-nurture dichotomy looks at individuals as groups, rather than at a single individual. It considers what proportion of the difference between individuals within these groups is due to differences between genetic inheritances, and what proportion of the difference between individuals within these groups is due to differences between environmental conditions. Looking at the identical twin example again, we can access the differences in mental and physical health between the twins, and then effectively evaluate how much of this different is due to inborn factors, and how much is due to other non-genetic factors. This new way of dealing with the nature-nurture dichotomy also allows for the use of a heritability estimate, which is a descriptive statistic that calculates how much of variability between individuals is due to genetic variation.

nodes.title: Robert Tryon's Study On Nature vs. Nurture
Robert Tryon's Study On Nature vs. Nurture
W7L1 Nature vs. Nurture examples [Errina Ma_Psychobubble]
The Study of Nature vs. Nurture

typeData.textContent:
Although we have now learned that our genes and our environment equally effect each other to determine a person’s characteristics and/or behaviour. It is still a very fascinating idea especially when you look at both Nature and Nurture individually and not combined.

I think we have all, at some point in our lives, heard ‘you’re just naturally smart’ or ‘it’s in your genetics’. This is an example of the nature argument that was widely supported by European Ethologists. Plato and Descartes were both believers that our characteristics are solely inherited and cannot be learned or taught by the environment that we live in. However, North American Behaviorists argued the contrary with John Locke stating that humans are ‘blank slates’ when we are born and and ‘everything that we are and all of our knowledge is determined by our experience’ (Cherry, 2020) meaning our characteristics are solely dependent on the environment in which we were raised and the people around us who influenced us.

The most common studies that have been done to solidify each sides arguments have been twin studies. Both monozygotic and dizygotic twins are centered around the nature vs nurture studies as monozygotic twins are twins who share the 100% of the same genes (split from one egg), whereas dizygotic twins are twins who share 50% of the same genes (two separate eggs). Studies tend to research the IQ of monozygotic twins when they were reared apart from birth into two different home environments (one more wealthy and the other less well off) and compare their IQ’s to determine if there were any differences which would indicate an effect of nurture. Another popular study studies dizygotic twin participants in the same household and compare their IQ’s to determine if genes were the cause of these differences.

Bibliography

Cherry, Kendra. “What to Know About Nature vs. Nurture.” Verywell Mind, 2020, www.verywellmind.com/what-is-nature-versus-nurture-2795392.

nodes.title: Gender in Nature vs. Nurture (Evelyn Sun)

typeData.textContent:
There has long been a debate about whether gender was constructed through nurture or nature. Psychologist John Money is a strong proponent of the "gender neutrality theory."
He believed that children were born without gender differences, and their cognition of gender almost all came from the acquired environment and education. If children are "gender redistributed" at an early age and properly cultivated, they can all get rid of their original gender. Therefore, he once made an experiment about gender reassignment on a boy named Bruce, who lost his penis in a cauterization. His testicles were cut off, fitted with a woman's vulva, and renamed Brenda. Also, their parents were instructed not to tell Brenda the truth that she was born a boy in order to reshape her cognition. Brenda also had a twin brother named Brian with the same genes and the environment who could be a perfect control group. 

After the gender reassignment, Money observed his progress regularly and gave Brenda a series of "nurture" to help her understand her gender, which including telling her about the differences between men and women by taking nude photos of her and her brother and letting two children have sexual rehearsal play which is very brutal and controversial. When the twins were nine years old, Money declared the case a success as "John and Joan case”, and he concluded that gender is determined by nurture, not by nature because, for the first few years, her parents pointed out that Brenda was indeed more feminine, cleaner and less messy than her brother, also Brenda had no idea she was born a boy. 

However, more negative details were eliminated in Money’s report. Brenda actually didn’t feel like a girl, and she was isolated and bullied by her peers. Her brother Brian was later diagnosed with schizophrenia. After Brenda’s parents told her the fact of gender reassignment, she decided to live as a man, changed her name to David, and did gender-reassignment surgery back to male. However, in the last years of David's life, there were multiple shocks and pressures. Brian died from taking too many antidepressants, and David died at the age of 38 by shooting himself in the head with a truncated shotgun.

nodes.title: Is Bullying Genetic? (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: A Closer Look at the Nature vs. Nurture Debate of Bullying in the Workplace

typeData.textContent:
As we continue to deepen our understanding of human behaviour through the lens of psychology, we learn more and more about how our behaviour is influenced by a variety of factors. Our most recent understanding regarding the Nature vs. Nurture debate of behaviour strongly suggests that both nature and nurture play a role in human behaviour. So, what does this mean for bullying, a behaviour we so often relate to the mean kid on the school playground? While the environmental origins of bullying behaviours may not come as a surprise to you, there has been evidence found to suggest that the aggressiveness in bullies is partly genetic as well. Harvey et al., in their 2009 article “Bullying in the 21st Century Global Organization: An Ethical Perspective” take a deeper dive into the hidden mechanics behind bullies in the adult workplace.

This article seeks to unravel the mystery behind the nature, or bullying behaviour influenced by the innate genetic make-up of an individual, and the nurture, the learned behaviours from environments allowing bullying to perpetuate. Bullying is often a misunderstood, misdiagnosed, and a mismanaged behaviour in work environments (Harvey et al., 2009).  Although we all have some idea of what a bully is, to take a closer look at this scientifically, we have to come up with a precise, consistent, and accurate definition. Luckily, we already have one:

Bullying is repeated acts and practices that are directed at one or more workers, which are unwanted by the victim(s), which may be done deliberately or unconsciously, but clearly cause humiliation, offence, and distress, and may interfere with job performance and/or cause unpleasant working environment (Einarsen, 1999, p. 17)

Bullying can manifest in a variety of actions or behaviours. In the work environment, bullying can fall into one of five categories: 1) Name calling by a bully in public; 2) Using a scapegoat by placing the fault for failure on a stigmatized individual or group in the organization; 3) Increasing work pressure to perform on one individual/group beyond the level of expectations of others in the organization; 4) Sexual harassment of coworkers generally by individuals with a power differential; 5) Physical abuse or harm to a stigmatized individual or group (Harvey et al., 2009). 

The Nature of Bullying

Contrary to intuition, there is strong evidence that supports the idea that there may be natural “causes” that play a role in one taking on bullying tendencies. Such causes appear to center on gene defects and the absorption of essential hormones in the brain. In fact, the contention that there is a biological connection between inherited characteristics and aggression is supported by numerous longitudinal studies. Although Harvey et al. make no claim that with its biological markers that bullying is predestined, they posit that there is a “strong connection between inherited genes and the propensity for individuals to become aggressive in certain environmental contexts” (2009). In sum, there appear to be three leading biological influences on the propensity to exhibit aggression behaviour: 1) Brain Related Issues. Individuals with pathological, antisocial, and aggressive behaviours exhibit significantly lower uptake of glucose in the prefrontal cortex, an area of the brain generally associated with self-control, maturity, judgement, reasoning, and aggression; 2) Mutation of Specific Genes. Impulsive, aggressive males often have a malfunctioning gene which usually codes for an enzyme called monoamine oxidase A (MAOA). This gene metabolizes serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine. The mutation can cause the gene to metabolize unbalanced levels of these chemicals, leading to high levels of aggression and antisocial behaviour; 3) Overly developed immune system. Interestingly, there seems to be a strong correlation with individuals who display aggressive behaviour and who have a strong immune system with aggression-associated immunity association strongest for CD4 cells and B-lymphocytes.
Although these markers for aggressive and bullying behaviour can be observed, we must remember that there is minimum certainty to the prediction of it; that is to say, individuals with these conditions do not automatically become bullies (Harvey et al., 2009). Instead, the increasing occurrence of bullying in the workplace is primarily attributed to environmental conditions, which may manifest through a variety of factors, such as deficiences in work design (lack of or improper supervision, or environments conducive to allow bullying), deficiencies in leadership behaviour (lack of training or management on how to address bullying), a socially exposed position of the victim (abuse of power differentials in the workplace), and low morale standard in the department (workplace culture and climate held to low standards, where bullying is not only tolerated, but expected). It can also arise due to learned antisocial behaviours from childhood or as an imitation of aggression experience in home or in other areas in life.

In short, like most human behaviours, both genes and environment play an intricate role in determining if someone will exhibit bullying behaviours in their life. However, this may just complicate how you feel about someone who may be aggressive, unkind, and antagonizing in your life: if it is in their genes, how does this change, if at all, how we interact and deal with the people like this in our lives?


Works Cited:

Michael Harvey, D. T. (2009). Bullying in the 21st Century Global Organization: An Ethical Perspective. Journal of Business Ethics, 27-40.

nodes.title: Week 7- Nature vs Nurture in Creativity (Michelle Ahmadi)
nodes.description: An essay outlining the role Nature and Nurture both play in one's creativity.

typeData.textContent:
American poet and civil rights activist Maya Angelou is considered one of the most creative minds to ever exist. It is documented that she was never able to write at home and she would opt for staying in a motel or a hotel to do her work. In addition, she always worked with a dictionary, Bible, deck of cards and a bottle of Sherry near her. Did her parents also work best when away from home, and did they also find comfort in a cup of Sherry or two?  or was it years of Miss Angelou's hard work and helpful habits that she grew comfortable with to aid  in her creativity. Is one’s creativity rooted in their genes, or how they were raised? Is it Nature or nurture that is responsible for one’s creativity? 

A plethora of research has been conducted on this subject.  And like everything else, we look back as far as we can to find the truth. It is said that ancient Greek and Roman poets and other creatives believed creativity visited upon oneself like a demon and it's not something that one would be able to learn but rather encounter. When reading about the creativity behind some of the great names like Shakespeare or Beethoven or Mozart, people seem to have a strong belief that this type of greatness cannot be learned. 

James Kauffman, professor of educational psychology at the University of Connecticut says you can train your brain by asking questions that have more than one answer. This is called Divergent thinking. 

Now consider an object, for the purposes of this activity we will be considering a pen. Now grab your phone, and set the timer app to 60 Seconds. I want you to think of all the possible things that a pen could be used for (ex: writing). note down how many things you can get, go!

The average number of answers an individual would be able to come up with is 10 to 12. if you got more than 10 to 12 answers, congratulations you are of the more creative minds in the world. If you got less than 10 to 12 answers, that's okay because Dr. Kaufman says that with enough practice in divergent thinking, one can display more characteristics of a creative individual.

Till this day, no one knows Maya Angelou the way she did. We won't ever know how much her genetics we're cause of her creativity or if it was her life experiences that raised an artist. And as for everyone else, psychologists believe that it is actually both nature and nurture that contribute to one's creativity.

nodes.title: Lamarckism: it's rise and fall (Kelly Tat)

typeData.textContent:
In 1809, Jean-Baptiste Lamarck created Lamarckism as a theory of evolution that involves the passing down of behavioural and physical traits through generations based on experience. In other words, as the environment changes, an animal may adapt to the changes as new circumstances arise and these adaptations may be passed down through generations. For example, a giraffe who would like to reach more than the bottom of the tree would stretch its neck, and gradually, their necks and limbs may grow longer and subsequently be a trait that is inherited by following generations.

While the theory had its influence on evolution during the 19th century, it was questioned by several individuals and later almost completely discredited by the 1930s. Charles Darwin was one of the significant individuals who shared their thoughts and expanded on the concept of evolution. While he accepted that a part of evolution was accounted for by the heredity of acquired characteristics, which refers to characteristics that have been developed as a direct response to environmental changes, Darwin proposed a separate hypothesis, called pangenesis, which involved the movement of “gemmule” particles that moved through our bloodstream that caused changes that could be passed down from parent to child. 

August Weismann was another individual who conducted experiments on the basis of the transmission of acquired characteristics, however, his experiments proved to be a step towards the end of Lamarckism. His experiments included chopping off the tails of rats in efforts to create a tailless type. The results of his experiments, which did not result in a tailless type, simply demonstrated the flaws in the arguments often used to support the principles of Lamarckism. 

Despite the wide ranging views of the accuracy of Lamarckism through the years, I think it is very interesting to expand on any given topic that demonstrates a progression of knowledge. Even if Lamarckism as a whole concept is no longer a dominant view for evolution and has, essentially, been lost as a scientific hypothesis, it has played its role as a stepping stone in the study of heredity.

Bibliography:

The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica. (2017, October 11). Experimental testing of Lamarckism. Retrieved July 11, 2020, from https://www.britannica.com/science/Lamarckism/Experimental-testing-of-Lamarckism

nodes.title: Transgenerational Epigenetics vs. Lamarckism (Shawn Yee)
nodes.description: An overview of the similarities and history of transgenerational epigenetics and lamarckism.

typeData.textContent:
A Brief History of Epigenetics

Epigenetics, a term that was created in the late 1800s by cell biologists, used in a wide debate surrounding the field at the time: How is an organism, created out of many different cell types, arise out of a single fertilized egg? During this time, there were two main schools of thought: preformationism, which stated that cells had preformed elements which grew in size as the cell grew, and epigenesis, which thought that chemical reactions within the cell carried out an intricate developmental plan (Felsenfeld, 2014).

This development plan was supported by the discovery of DNA and chromosomes in cells, and eventually, the definition of epigenetics was modified in the past 50 years until its current definition: “the study of mitotically and/or meiotically heritable changes in gene function that cannot be explained by changes in DNA sequence” (Riggs et al., 1996, as cited in Felsenfeld, 2014). At present, two major epigenetic mechanisms include histone remodelling and DNA methylation (Barnes, 2020). These changes do not affect the actual sequence of DNA, but the structures around the DNA, evidently shown in the name epigenetics, as the Greek prefix “epi-” roughly translates to “above” or “near” (Genetics, 2020).

The subject of transgenerational epigenetics concerns how epigenetic effects are transferred across generations. Studies have showed that environmental factors can influence mice and their behaviours for quite a few generations (Barnes, 2020). To better understand this idea, let’s turn to a similar idea proposed by Jean-Baptiste Lamarck before Darwin’s theory of the evolution, now called Lamarckism.


Lamarckism

Lamarckism believed in the inheritance of “acquired traits,” which were traits gained through the experience of the organism. The conventional example that is used is the idea that giraffes developed long necks because during their lifetimes, they had to gradually stretch their necks to reach the leaves on higher and higher trees. This modification would then be subsequently passed down to the next generation of giraffes and so on, resulting in the overall increase in the lengths of giraffe necks (Michael, 2017).

This idea is incredibly similar to transgenerational epigenetics as it explores how the environmental is able to change the behaviour of subsequent generations. In the giraffe scenario, the pressure to extend your neck is analogous to the environmental effect in epigenetics.

Although Lamarkism was eventually disregarded when Darwin’s theory of evolution came out, Darwin previously supported Lamarck’s ideas, incorporating it into his own theory. He proposed the idea of “gemmules”, which would modify the germline under environmental stress, effectively allowing the environment to have an effect on subsequent generations (Michael, 2017; Heard & Martienssen, 2014).

To end, one thing that I did find interesting during my research was that although there have not been very many concrete pieces of evidence for epigenetic inheritance in humans, our culture is quite Lamarckian-adjacent. We teach our children about certain ideas from our experiences with our environment which has the ability to change their behaviours, or phenotype (Heard & Martienssen, 2014). All in all, the similarities between transgenerational epigenetics and Lamarckism allow us to learn from their beliefs and clearly show how the past can resemble the present and even the future.

Bibiolography:

Barnes, S. J. (2020). Week 7, Lecture 3: Basics of Genetics and Epigenetics. Department of Psychology, Univerisity of British Columbia.

Felsenfeld, G. (2014). A Brief History of Epigenetics. Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Biology, 6(1). https://doi.org/10.1101/cshperspect.a018200

Genetics Home Reference. (2020, July 7). What is epigenetics? https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/primer/howgeneswork/epigenome

Heard, E., & Martienssen, R. A. (2014). Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance: myths and mechanisms. Cell, 157(1), 95-109. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2014.02.045

Michael, R. (2017, October 11). Lamarckism. Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved July 10, 2020, from https://www.britannica.com/science/Lamarckism/Experimental-testing-of-Lamarckism

nodes.title: Week 7 – The Epigenetics of Childhood Trauma (Sherry Wang)

typeData.textContent:
Some external factors such as diet, drugs and chemicals are capable of turning genes on or off without modifying the basic DNA sequences. Such changes in gene expression are heritable and can be passed on to several generations. This is the so-called epigenetics.

There is a series of studies showing that epigenetics plays an important role in the persisting effects of early experiences. Serious stressors, especially early in life, can change the phenotypes and have long-lasting effects on both physical and mental health. Much of this work was done by Michael Meaney and his colleagues at McGill University.

Maternal behaviors in rats

Their first experiment examines the effects that different mothering styles have on baby rats. There are two groups of mother rats, one spends much time licking their pups, which is called “high lickers”, whereas the other one spends little time doing so, which is called “low lickers”. The researchers found that highly licked rat pups are much less fearful and have better control of stress as adults when placed in a stressful environment. The rising level of serotonin in pups leads to a decrease in DNA methylation, which regulates the level of cortisol, a stress hormone, and helps them to get back to normal quickly.

Childhood abuse

Such long-term impact of childhood experiences not only exists in rats but also humans. In a recent study, Meaney’s team extracted the hippocampal samples of 12 men who committed suicide when they were 35 years old and had the experience of childhood abuse, and 12 men who committed suicide when they were 35 years old but with no experience of childhood abuse. The researchers separated them into two groups and compared each group with a control group of 12 men who died at around the same age but had no experience of abuse and suicide. The results showed that the level of DNA methylation of the group who had a history of abuse and committed suicide had increased compared to others, while there was no significant difference between the other two groups, regardless of whether they died of suicide.

To sum up, childhood trauma can actually influence our gene expression and result in a higher risk of developing mental and physical health problems later in life. Therefore, adults should endeavor to create a safe and warm family environment, which will protect not only their children but also the following generations.

Reference

https://www.psychologytoday.com/ca/blog/psyched/201909/the-epigenetics-childhood-trauma-0

https://www.mcgill.ca/newsroom/channels/news/childhood-trauma-has-life-long-effect-genes-and-brain-104667

McGowan, P. O., Sasaki, A., D’Alessio, A. C., Dymov, S., Labonté, B., Szyf, M., Turecki, G., & Meaney, M. J. (2009). Epigenetic regulation of the glucocorticoid receptor in human brain associates with childhood abuse. Nature neuroscience, 12(3), 342–348. https://doi.org/10.1038/nn.2270

nodes.title: The Interaction Between Environment and Genetics -- A Study of Intelligence

typeData.textContent:
At the tail end of World War II, German forces occupying the Netherlands placed an embargo on inland shipping into Western Netherlands. The embargo made it impossible for food to enter cities. This, combined with freezing temperatures in the winter of 1945 that made transport of food across canals impossible, caused a severe shortage of food in Western Netherlands. During this time, the average intake of food was limited to 400 calories per day (Shultz, 2010). The Dutch people were liberated by the allies in April of 1945, but by that time, the Dutch population had been severely affected by the famine. 

Years later, however, the effects of the Dutch famine were still being felt. The Dutch Famine Birth Cohort Study found that the children of women who were pregnant during the famine had lingering health problems including increased risk of obesity, cardiovascular disease and diabetes (Shultz, 2010). These same conditions were not found in children who were conceived during periods not subject to famine. This highlights the importance of gestation as a period of development in relation to epigenetic markers. Children who displayed an increased risk for various health defects were also associated with changes in DNA methylation at a few key genes (Shultz, 2010). 

Original studies published about the Dutch famine found transgenerational effects -- they found that the grandchildren of undernourished children during the famine had increased prevalence of chronic diseases. However, further studies have contested these results (Veenendaal et al., 2013). Since controlled studies of transgenerational epigenetics on humans are impossible due to ethics concerns, scientists have to rely on historical data that is impacted by a multitude of conflicting factors. While these findings are still under review, the potential for trauma to affect descendants generations later has significant implications on our understanding of transgenerational epigenetics. As well, the Dutch famine is important in the study of the potential epigenetic basis in the developmental origins of adult diseases. 


References: 

Schulz, L. (2010, September 28). The Dutch Hunger Winter and the developmental origins of health and disease. Retrieved July 16, 2020, from https://www.pnas.org/content/107/39/16757

Veenendaal, M., Painter, R., de Rooij, S., Bossuyt, P., van der Post, J., & Gluckman, P. et al. (2013). Transgenerational effects of prenatal exposure to the 1944-45 Dutch famine. BJOG: An International Journal Of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, 120(5), 548-554. doi: 10.1111/1471-0528.12136

typeData.textContent:
Epigenetic clocks such as the multi-tissue Horvath clock, are used to determine one’s biological age; in comparison to our chronological age, biological age is a way to identify the state of our cells and chromosomes. Signs of biological aging includes shortening telomeres in which our chromosomes start fraying, senescent cells, and epigenetic-induced alterations in our DNA (refer back to methylation and histone).

We can slow down aging through maintaining a healthy lifestyle. While we are in our natural state, our body has enough energy conserved to focus on growing and reproducing, but in other cases, “survival” genes such as sirtuins, mTORs and AMPK can kick in to induce cellular repair and protection. We can create a similar scenario through maintaining a healthy diet, reducing protein intake, periodic fasting and high intensity work outs. Similarly, occasional changes in our environment and stepping out of our comfort zone can induce a similar effect.

Now the question is: Is it possible to reverse aging?
Actually, studies that have been recently conducted in the past decade have shown signs of making breakthrough through arguably one of the greatest stem cell breakthrough since their discovery: the Yamanaka factors and the creation of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS). 

[…Continue this topic be watching the related H5P content…]

References:
Sinclair, D. A., & Oberdoerffer, P. (2009). The ageing epigenome: Damaged beyond repair? Ageing Research Reviews, 8(3), 189-198. https://doi-org.ezproxy.library.ubc.ca/10.1016/j.arr.2009.04.004

Veritasium. (2019). How to Slow Aging (and even reverse it) [Film]. Retrieved from: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QRt7LjqJ45k

nodes.title: Epigenetics and Autism Quiz (Jeong Min Son)

typeData.textContent:
Epigenetics is modifications to the genome that do not modify the underlying DNA sequence. It functions by modifying the genes so that they are turned on or off. The genes being modified causes a change in the phenotype of the organism. It was originally thought that epigenetics could not be passed down through generations but that thought is beginning to change. 

Epigenetics has been found to play a role in different diseases: 
- Cancer has been linked to hypermethylation of genes and histone modifications causing a variety of cancers depending on where the epigenetics is. For example, hypermethylation of the APC gene has been found to lead to esophageal cancer. 
- Autoimmune diseases have also been linked to different epigenetics mechanisms. Asthma and the epigenetic modification associated with it has been found to be heritable. The epigenetics modification was found to transfer more from the parental mother than that of the parental father. 
- Brain development is also very susceptible to epigenetics. The first couple years of a child’s life is critical for proper brain development. This can lead to different psychological disorders later on in life from the associated epigenetics modification. Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and others have been found to be a results of hypomethylation and hypermethylation of various genes. 

Not all of the above epigenetics mechanism have been found to be heritable as of yet but if they do this will further emphasize the need to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Smoking has been heavily linked to cause cancer. The use of tabacco and the methylation that occurred in the lung cells lead to cancer. Knowing that it could potentially be inherited to your offspring as well as any other epigenetics modifications caused by your life should make us more aware of our actions to protect the future generations. 

References: 
Alegría-Torres, J., Baccarelli, A., & Bollati, V. (2011, June). Epigenetics and lifestyle. Retrieved 
            July 16, 2020, from https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3752894/

Moosavi, A., & Motevalizadeh Ardekani, A. (2016, November). Role of Epigenetics in Biology and 
            Human Diseases. Retrieved July 16, 2020, from 
            https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5075137/

nodes.title: Week 7 Thoughts on Genes vs Exnvironment (Carlos Li)

typeData.textContent:
This week’s content was more focussed towards human genetics and behaviour. After having several weeks of content that I had already previously learned about, I was refreshed to see a topic in which I haven’t had much prior exposure to. In fact, before starting this week's material, I always thought that genes were the main factor in determining one's behaviour. 
I used to believe in the range of reaction theory, in which genes would set a boundary for a behaviour's potential and that it was up to the person to determine how far they would take that potential. Throughout my life, whenever I saw someone excel at a certain behaviour, I always thought that they had a genetic advantage. For example, when seeing a group of people running, I would always think that the fastest person had a genetic advantage over the other runners. At the same time, I also believed that that faster person also had to work hard to fulfill the potential given to him by his genetic makeup. 
When learning about Robert Tryon's experiment with maze running mice, I furthered my belief in the range of reaction theory. Robert Tryon attempted to contrast the view that behaviour develops through learning. What he did was selectively breed mice and measure their abilities to complete a maze. He mated the best females with the best males and the worst females with the worst males. By doing so, he was able to compare strong genetic makeups against weaker genetic makeups. At the same time, he repeated this process for twenty-one generations and by the eighth he noticed that there wasn't much of an overlap in abilities. From his experiment, it can be concluded that genes influence behaviour. However, it also doesn’t rule out the fact that the environment may also contribute to the development of behaviour.
Later on, I learned that genes weren't the only factor in determining behaviour and that environment also played a role. In addition to this, this week's content also taught me that it's hard to ask whether genes or the environment plays a larger role in behaviour. It shifted me into focusing more on how much either factor plays in the development of behaviour.
