nodes.title: Is Bullying Genetic? (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: A Closer Look at the Nature vs. Nurture Debate of Bullying in the Workplace

typeData.textContent:
As we continue to deepen our understanding of human behaviour through the lens of psychology, we learn more and more about how our behaviour is influenced by a variety of factors. Our most recent understanding regarding the Nature vs. Nurture debate of behaviour strongly suggests that both nature and nurture play a role in human behaviour. So, what does this mean for bullying, a behaviour we so often relate to the mean kid on the school playground? While the environmental origins of bullying behaviours may not come as a surprise to you, there has been evidence found to suggest that the aggressiveness in bullies is partly genetic as well. Harvey et al., in their 2009 article “Bullying in the 21st Century Global Organization: An Ethical Perspective” take a deeper dive into the hidden mechanics behind bullies in the adult workplace.

This article seeks to unravel the mystery behind the nature, or bullying behaviour influenced by the innate genetic make-up of an individual, and the nurture, the learned behaviours from environments allowing bullying to perpetuate. Bullying is often a misunderstood, misdiagnosed, and a mismanaged behaviour in work environments (Harvey et al., 2009). Although we all have some idea of what a bully is, to take a closer look at this scientifically, we have to come up with a precise, consistent, and accurate definition. Luckily, we already have one:

Bullying is repeated acts and practices that are directed at one or more workers, which are unwanted by the victim(s), which may be done deliberately or unconsciously, but clearly cause humiliation, offence, and distress, and may interfere with job performance and/or cause unpleasant working environment (Einarsen, 1999, p. 17)

Bullying can manifest in a variety of actions or behaviours. In the work environment, bullying can fall into one of five categories: 1) Name calling by a bully in public; 2) Using a scapegoat by placing the fault for failure on a stigmatized individual or group in the organization; 3) Increasing work pressure to perform on one individual/group beyond the level of expectations of others in the organization; 4) Sexual harassment of coworkers generally by individuals with a power differential; 5) Physical abuse or harm to a stigmatized individual or group (Harvey et al., 2009).

The Nature of Bullying

Contrary to intuition, there is strong evidence that supports the idea that there may be natural “causes” that play a role in one taking on bullying tendencies. Such causes appear to center on gene defects and the absorption of essential hormones in the brain. In fact, the contention that there is a biological connection between inherited characteristics and aggression is supported by numerous longitudinal studies. Although Harvey et al. make no claim that with its biological markers that bullying is predestined, they posit that there is a “strong connection between inherited genes and the propensity for individuals to become aggressive in certain environmental contexts” (2009). In sum, there appear to be three leading biological influences on the propensity to exhibit aggression behaviour: 1) Brain Related Issues. Individuals with pathological, antisocial, and aggressive behaviours exhibit significantly lower uptake of glucose in the prefrontal cortex, an area of the brain generally associated with self-control, maturity, judgement, reasoning, and aggression; 2) Mutation of Specific Genes. Impulsive, aggressive males often have a malfunctioning gene which usually codes for an enzyme called monoamine oxidase A (MAOA). This gene metabolizes serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine. The mutation can cause the gene to metabolize unbalanced levels of these chemicals, leading to high levels of aggression and antisocial behaviour; 3) Overly developed immune system. Interestingly, there seems to be a strong correlation with individuals who display aggressive behaviour and who have a strong immune system with aggression-associated immunity association strongest for CD4 cells and B-lymphocytes.

Although these markers for aggressive and bullying behaviour can be observed, we must remember that there is minimum certainty to the prediction of it; that is to say, individuals with these conditions do not automatically become bullies (Harvey et al., 2009). Instead, the increasing occurrence of bullying in the workplace is primarily attributed to environmental conditions, which may manifest through a variety of factors, such as deficiences in work design (lack of or improper supervision, or environments conducive to allow bullying), deficiencies in leadership behaviour (lack of training or management on how to address bullying), a socially exposed position of the victim (abuse of power differentials in the workplace), and low morale standard in the department (workplace culture and climate held to low standards, where bullying is not only tolerated, but expected). It can also arise due to learned antisocial behaviours from childhood or as an imitation of aggression experience in home or in other areas in life.

In short, like most human behaviours, both genes and environment play an intricate role in determining if someone will exhibit bullying behaviours in their life. However, this may just complicate how you feel about someone who may be aggressive, unkind, and antagonizing in your life: if it is in their genes, how does this change, if at all, how we interact and deal with the people like this in our lives?

Works Cited

Michael Harvey, D. T. (2009). Bullying in the 21st Century Global Organization: An Ethical Perspective. Journal of Business Ethics, 27-40.

nodes.title: 7 Misunderstood Points about Evolution Review (Ashley Kim)

typeData.textContent:
1. Humans are not higher up on evolutionary 'bush'.
- Humans are actually the last surviving species of family (i.e. hominids), which has existed for a very short period of time. On the evolutionary bush, humans are located at the very right bottom tip, just before Neanderthals (extinct).

2. Fewer than 1% of products (i.e. species) of evolution still exist. 
- Surprisingly, 99% of species that existed on Earth are now extinct. 

3. Evolution is not necessarily a slow, gradual process.
- Sudden changes in the environment can trigger rapid evolutionary changes, as the traits that are best suited for the environment would also change and cause a shift in the direction of natural selection.

4. Evolution doesn't progress to perfection. 
- Organisms don't always progress to "get better" through evolution. 
- For example, blobfish have no muscles and float around, waiting for organisms to swim into their mouth for them to consume. Although they are perfectly adapted to their environment (deep waters that are rich in organisms), one wouldn't necessarily say that their design is perfect. 

5. Not all existing behaviours or structures are adaptive. 
- Some structures or behaviours appear as by-product of other adaptive structures or behaviours, which are known as spandrels. 
- Our belly-button is considered as a spandrel, as it is needed in our neo-natal & pre-natal environment (we're attached to and receive nutrients from our mother by the umbilical cord), but serves no purpose in adult organism. 

6. Not all adaptive characteristics evolved to perform current function. 
- There are exaptations, which are characteristics that evolved to perform one function, but were later co-opted to perform another function. 
- It is believed that feather have first evolved for heat regulation, but were later co-opted for flight.

7. Similarities between species don't necessarily mean that species have common evolutionary origins. 
- "Just because some species have wings, it doesn't mean that all of them have a common evolutionary origins."

- HOMOlogous structures: structures that are similar because they HAVE common evolutionary origin.
     - Ex) bat wings, human arm 

- ANAlogous structures: structures that are similar BUT DON'T HAVE common evolutionary origin.
     - Ex) bird wings, bee wings

To better understand this idea, let’s turn to a similar idea proposed by Jean-Baptiste Lamarck before Darwin’s theory of the evolution, now called Lamarckism.


Lamarckism

Lamarckism believed in the inheritance of “acquired traits,” which were traits gained through the experience of the organism. The conventional example that is used is the idea that giraffes developed long necks because during their lifetimes, they had to gradually stretch their necks to reach the leaves on higher and higher trees. This modification would then be subsequently passed down to the next generation of giraffes and so on, resulting in the overall increase in the lengths of giraffe necks (Michael, 2017).

This idea is incredibly similar to transgenerational epigenetics as it explores how the environmental is able to change the behaviour of subsequent generations. In the giraffe scenario, the pressure to extend your neck is analogous to the environmental effect in epigenetics.

Although Lamarkism was eventually disregarded when Darwin’s theory of evolution came out, Darwin previously supported Lamarck’s ideas, incorporating it into his own theory. He proposed the idea of “gemmules”, which would modify the germline under environmental stress, effectively allowing the environment to have an effect on subsequent generations (Michael, 2017; Heard & Martienssen, 2014).

To end, one thing that I did find interesting during my research was that although there have not been very many concrete pieces of evidence for epigenetic inheritance in humans, our culture is quite Lamarckian-adjacent. We teach our children about certain ideas from our experiences with our environment which has the ability to change their behaviours, or phenotype (Heard & Martienssen, 2014). All in all, the similarities between transgenerational epigenetics and Lamarckism allow us to learn from their beliefs and clearly show how the past can resemble the present and even the future.

Bibiolography:

Felsenfeld, G. (2014). A Brief History of Epigenetics. Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Biology, 6(1). https://doi.org/10.1101/cshperspect.a018200

Genetics Home Reference. (2020, July 7). What is epigenetics? https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/primer/howgeneswork/epigenome

Heard, E., & Martienssen, R. A. (2014). Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance: myths and mechanisms. Cell, 157(1), 95-109. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2014.02.045

Michael, R. (2017, October 11). Lamarckism. Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved July 10, 2020, from https://www.britannica.com/science/Lamarckism/Experimental-testing-of-Lamarckism

typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the last section of this week’s tapestry. In this node, we will learn about the interactions of genes with the environment. 
Gene-environment interaction is when two different genotypes respond to environmental variation in different ways. Studying gene-environment interaction is important for improving accuracy and precision in the assessment of genetic and environmental influences (Ottman, 2008). The current scientific opinion towards the nature vs. nurture debate is that all traits are influenced by both genetic and environmental differences, neither genetic differences nor environmental differences are the only cause of phenotypic variation (Koehl, 2015). They work together that “our genes influence our environment, and our environment influences the expression of our genes” (Spielman, et al., 2018, pp. 78-79).
Now I will introduce one example that shows gene-environment interaction.



References:

Koehl, M. (2015). Gene-environment interaction in programming hippocampal plasticity: Focus on adult neurogenesis. Frontiers in Molecular Neuroscience, 8:41. doi:10.3389/fnmol.2015.00041

Ottman, R. (2008). Gene-Environment Interaction: Definitions and Study Designs [Abstract]. Nature Precedings. doi:10.1038/npre.2008.2653.1

Spielman, R. M., Dumper, K., Jenkins, W., Lacombe, A., Lovett, M., & Perlmutter, M. (2018). Psychology (pp. 78-79). Houston, TX: OpenStax, Rice University.
